There's been so much controversy around this and you may have seen a headline like this one from out.com reading US votes against UN
Ban on death penalty for homosexuality it put people up in arms saying how is this the United States? How is the u.s.
not
Condemning the death penalty for people just being gay the
Resolution specifically blocking "the imposition of the death penalty as a sanction for specific forms of conduct such as apostasy
blasphemy adultery and consensual same-sex relations" some of the other countries that joined the United States with this nuovo included the UAE, Saudi Arabia,
which of course currently maintains a death penalty for the crime of sodomy ,Iraq, India, Qatar ,Bangladesh
And the list continues ultimately though the motion did pass in a vote of 27 to 13
But of course that brings us back to the question of why? Why would the United States do this well it turns out the situation wasn't
As simple as many of the outlets made you believe despite
What all the headlines said this resolution wasn't just about the death penalty for homosexuality
This resolution was about the death penalty in general
It was literally titled the question of the death penalty
Resolution among other things urged States to end the death penalty abolish it get rid of it it also goes into those
specifics like no death penalty for homosexuality another way sites could have misled people, they could have said America voted no on
Condemning the death penalty against pregnant women thats in there as well
There's also language in the document that read death penalty is a form of torture or other cruel inhuman or degrading
Treatment or punishment and of course there are places in the United States where the death penalty is legal

Of voting no or abstaining when it comes to the death penalty and in response to the outrage US ambassador to the UN Nikki Haley
Tweeted the vote that took place in Geneva is the same U.S. Vote that took place under the Obama admin
It was not a vote against LGBT the press secretary of the State Department also tried to clarify
Why the United States voted no the United States is disappointed to have voted against that resolution
We voted against that resolution because of broader concerns with the resolutions approach in condemning the death penalty in
All circumstances and it called for the abolition of the death penalty altogether
We had hoped for a balanced and inclusive

the United States
